justification: “Cognitive load was assessed prior to exposure, immediately after exposure and at a later follow-up using a 15-item Remote Associates Test (RAT).”
The nuisance-variable section lists “regulation tendencies (ERQ) (Gross & John, 2003)” as a measured variable, indicating the ERQ was used to assess emotion-regulation tendencies.
Depression appears among nuisance variables: “depression (BDI-II)” showing the construct of depression was measured with the BDI-II.
The same nuisance-variable list includes “anxiety (STAI)”, linking anxiety to the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory.
Both Study 1 nuisance variables and Studies 2–3 measures mention “intolerance of uncertainty (IUS)” as the instrument assessing this construct.
Discussing common emotion measures, the introduction notes that self-report is often “captured through established measures (e.g., the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule) (Watson et al., 1988…).”

Study 2 methods: “participants completed individual difference measures, including the Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ), the Difficulties with Emotion Regulation Survey (DERS)…,” indicating the DERS operationalizes difficulties in emotion regulation.
During exposure participants “were then fitted with heart-rate monitors,” showing physiological arousal was recorded via heart-rate monitoring.
